The multitranche financing facility (MFF) amounting to $50 million 
will help fund the Investment Program and represents about 45% 
of  the  total  financing.  The  individual  and  periodic  financing 
requests  (PFR)  will  be  converted  into  two  loans  in  line  with 
individual  project  readiness,  as  well  as  policy,  safeguards, 
financial  management,  and  fiduciary  oversight.  The  project  loans 
will  be  made  from  ordinary  capital  resources  (OCR)  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB). The utilization period of the facility will 
be  7  years.  The  Government  has  entered  into  a  Framework 
Financing  Agreement  (FFA)  with  ADB.  Pursuant  to  the  FFA,  the 
Government has submitted to ADB the first PFR in the amount of 
$22 million. The first PFR is presented to the Board together with 
the  FFA.  Prior  to  ADB  acceptance  of  the  second  PFR,  ADB  will 
ensure that the Government, the Executing Agency (EA), and the 
PIA  comply  fully  with  the  terms  and  conditions  of  the  FFA.  An 
ADB  team  will  conduct  due  diligence  to  this  effect  to  ensure  that 
the  terms  and  conditions  are  satisfactorily  adhered  to.  The 
individual  PFR  should  be  for  a  minimum  loan  amount  of  
$20 million. 
 
PRC’s  sustained  economic  growth  and  low  per  capita  energy 
consumption  are  driving  up  the  demand  for  electricity,  which  has 
outpaced economic growth in the last 3 years. The result is power 
shortages  in  many  parts  of  the  PRC.  The  power  shortages  have 
affected  the  rural  population  disproportionately.  With  coal-fired 
power plants supplying about 81% of the country’s electricity, the 
electricity  sector  is  a  major  air  polluter.  More  than  60%  of  the 
cities do not meet air quality standards. Acid rain falls on one third 
of  the  country.  The  Government  is  committed  to  minimize 
emissions  and  improve  air  quality.  In  2006,  it  enacted  the 
Renewable  Energy  Law,  which  is  expected  to  lead  to  about 
120  gigawatts  (GW)  of  additional  clean  and  renewable  energy  in 
the country by 2020. Small and medium hydropower development 
is  an  integral  part  of  the  renewable  energy  program  and  is 
expected to provide 80 GW of the additional capacity by 2020.  
 
In Gansu, about 81% of the electricity was produced by coal-fired 
power  plants  in  2005.  Thirteen  of  Gansu’s  14  cities  do  not  meet 
air  quality  standards;  its  capital,  Lanzhou,  has  the  worst  air 
pollution index  of  47  major  cities.  Some  parts  of  Gansu,  such  as 
the  Hexi  corridor,  have  faced  chronic  power  shortages  due  to 
limited local generation capacity and large distances from nearby 
power  plants.  Heihe  river,  flowing  in  the  remote  mountainous 
areas  of  Zhangye,  a  predominantly  rural  area  located  in  the 
middle of the Hexi corridor, presents an excellent source of clean 
and  renewable  energy  closer  to  the  power-deficient  area  in 
Gansu. ZCG and GPG are committed to utilize this clean energy 
source to provide benefits to Zhangye and the Hexi corridor in an 
environmentally sustainable manner.

The  Investment  Program  will  improve  the  reliability  of  electricity 
supply to rural consumers in Zhangye and the Hexi corridor. The 
Investment  Program  will  have  significant  positive  environment 
impacts in terms of air pollution avoided from alternative sources. 
The  system  planning  and  least-cost  analysis  show  that  the 
alternative  will  be  a  coal-fired  power  plant.  Based  on  this 
alternative,  the  avoided  emissions  were  estimated  at  a  yearly 
average of 260 tons (t) total suspended particulate, 2,100 t sulfur 
dioxide (SO2), 1,550 t nitrogen oxide (NOx), and 382,000 t carbon 
dioxide  (CO2).  On  completion,  the  Investment  Program  will  avoid 
about 1 million t of coal use per year of operation.

Risks and Assumptions 

The Investment Program will be carried out in a poor remote rural 
township.  It  will  require  no  resettlement,  only  small  nonfarming 
land  will  be  occupied,  affecting  less  than  15  households  in  all.  It 
will provide significant direct benefits to local communities through 
employment generated during construction and operation, access 
to  project  hospitals  and  schools,  additional  economic  activities 
that  may  be  supported by  more  affordable  and  reliable  electricity 
supply.  The  Investment  Program  will  also  provide  significant 
additional tax revenue to the local county government, which may 
be utilized to accelerate economic development.  
 
The projects under the Investment  Program are financially viable 
and  economically  attractive.  For  Project  1,  the  financial  internal 
rate of return is 5.84%, which is higher than the weighted average 
cost  of  capital  of  4.17%.  The  economic  internal  rate  of  return  is 
19.60%, higher than the ADB hurdle rate of 12%. Sensitivity tests 
and  risk  analysis  show  that  Project  1  will  be  economically  and 
financially viable even under a combination of adverse scenarios. 
The  potential  carbon  revenues  under  the  clean  development 
mechanism (CDM) will further improve the financial and economic 
benefits  from  the  Investment  Program.  The  CDM  benefits  are 
likely  to  provide  additional  revenues  estimated  to  be  about 
10–15% of the project costs.

2. 
The PRC has achieved and sustained an impressive economic growth averaging about 9% 
for  the  past  two  decades.  Compared  with  its  2000  level,  the  economy  is  expected  to  double  by 
2010  and  quadruple  by  2020.  Given  the  projected  growth  trajectory  and  the  relatively  low1 per

energy is expected to increase rapidly. The rapid pace of economic growth has created a strong 
demand  for  electricity.  Per  capita  electricity  consumption  has  more  than  quintupled,  increasing 
from 340 kilowatt-hours (kWh) in 1983 to 1,840 kWh in 2005.  
 
3. 
After  the  United  States,  the  PRC  has  the  second  largest  electricity  industry  in  the  world. 
Both the installed generation capacity and electricity generation increased at an annual average of 
more than 8% over the past two decades. Since 2002, the electricity demand has increased at an 
average of more than 13%. This resulted in serious power shortages in many areas of the PRC. By 
the end of 2005, the total installed capacity reached 508 gigawatts (GW) and electricity generation 
totaled 2,470 terawatt-hours (TWh), an increase of 13% over 2004. In the past 2 years, 117 GW of 
new  generation  capacity  was  added  to  overcome  electricity  shortages.  To  meet  the  projected 
demand, the installed capacity will have to double from the 2005 level to about 1,000 GW in 2020. 
One  of  the  key  challenges  to  maintain  the  sustained  economic  growth  is  to  significantly  lower 
energy intensity.2 Energy conservation and improved energy efficiency in the electricity sector are 
the highest priorities of the Government.  
 
4. 
In  the  PRC,  electricity  is  produced  overwhelmingly  by  coal.  In  2005,  the  coal-fired  power 
plants produced about 81%, while the hydropower plants (HPPs) produced only 15%. The PRC is

coal produced in 2005, which has resulted in serious environmental problems—50% of the nation’s 
sulfur dioxide (SO2) emissions, 80% of nitrogen oxide (NOX) emissions, and 26% of carbon dioxide 
(CO2)  emissions.  Coal  consumption  is  the  major  cause  of  poor  air  quality.  Acid  rain  caused 
primarily by SO2 and NOx falls on one third of the country. In 2005, of the PRC’s 342 major cities, 
only 128 met the acceptable air quality standards—national class II air quality standards. Six of the 
world’s most polluted cities are in the PRC. Lanzhou, the capital of Gansu Province has the worst

desertification  causes  poor  air  quality.  Of  Gansu’s  14  cities,  13  cities  do  not  meet  acceptable 
standards.

Key Problems and Constraints 

 
7.

electricity  shortages,  which  were  exacerbated  by  severe  drought  in  2003.  The  Gansu  electricity

environmental  pollution  have  disproportionately  affected  the  poor,  who  typically  rely  on  raw  coal

pronounced  shift  toward  clean  energy  would  reduce  pollution  loads,  energy  intensity,  and 
greenhouse gas.

Opportunities 

 
10. 
The Heihe river, originating between Qilian Mountain and Datong Mountain, is the second 
largest inland river in the PRC and the largest in the Hexi corridor. It traverses northwards through 
Qinghai  Province,  Gansu,  and  Inner  Mongolia  Autonomous  Region  over  a  length  of  more  than         
800  km.  The  river  section  from  Huangzhang  Temple  to  Yingluo  Gorge  (95  km  along  the  river)  in 
Zhangye  is an  excellent  source  of  hydropower.  In  this  95 km  section  of  the  river,  the  Heihe  river 
cascade hydropower development scheme has identified seven potential HPP sites (Map 2) with a 
total hydropower capacity of 645.5 megawatts (MW). All HPPs in the scheme are medium-sized, 
run-of-river power plants. Details of the scheme are in Appendix 2.  
 
11. 
The scheme is an excellent source of emission free and renewable energy located close to 
a  power-deficient  area,  in  a  designated  SO2  control  zone.5 The  scheme  is  part  of  the  least-cost 
generation  expansion  plan  in  Gansu  to  supply  reliable  and  affordable  electricity  to  the  rural 
population in Zhangye and Hexi corridor. The scheme is also referred to in the Heihe river basin 
plan, prepared by the Ministry of Water Resources and approved by the State Council in 2001. All 
the  HPP  sites  in  the  scheme  are  located  in  remote  mountainous  rural  areas  requiring  little  or  no 
resettlement.

The  Heihe  river  is  the  second  largest  inland  river  in  the  People’s  Republic  of  China

Enhanced  Environment  Sustainability.  The  scheme  involves  construction  of  seven

5. 
Support  for  Sustainable  Economic  Growth.  The  scheme  has  started  improving  the 
efficiency  and  reliability  of  the  electricity  supply  in  the  project  area,  thus  addressing  a  major 
constraint to economic growth in Zhangye. The scheme has provided an alternative to burning 
coal and biomass for cooking, with associated improvements in indoor air quality. The scheme 
has provided reliable electricity, a vital input to the local agriculture-based industries in Zhangye.  
 
C. 
 
6. 
Hydropower  Development  in  Gansu. Nine  river  systems  in  the  Yellow,  Yangtze,  and 
inland river drainage basins with an annual discharge of 61.4 billion cubic meters are the main 
water  resources  in  Gansu  province.  The  combined  hydropower  potential  is  estimated  at            
17 gigawatts (GW). The province has constructed 32 hydropower stations with a total installed 
generating  capacity  of  about  4  GW  and  an  annual  output  of  12  terrawatt-hours.  The  share  of 
HPP  has  declined  sharply  from  41%  in  2000  to  about  19%  in  2005  because  of  the  recent 
addition of coal-based generation capacity. In Gansu, hydropower potential is mainly in small to 
medium-sized HPPs in mountainous areas.3 Development of small- and medium-sized HPPs is 
a  local  government  responsibility.  Their  development  is  generally  constrained  by  the  local 
government’s  financing  capacity.  Private  sector  investment  in  hydropower  development  is 
limited  to  large  hydropower  projects  developed  by  major  power  utilities.  GPG  has  drawn  an 
extensive  plan  for  local  hydropower  development  to  double  the  present  capacity  of  4  GW  to 
about 8.5 GW by 2020. In the 11FYP, GPG aims to add about 2 GW of hydropower capacity. In 
the absence of innovative approaches to project financing and private sector participation, the 
accelerated development of hydropower in Gansu will be severely restricted.  
 
7.

emphasis on accelerated development of renewable energy, improvement of energy efficiency 
by 20%, and strengthening of rural infrastructure to address the imbalance between urban and

quality  standards  in  all  cities.  Development  of  renewable  energy  sources  and  suitable 
hydrothermal generation mix are priorities in achieving that development goal. GPG also aims to 
achieve  100%  electrification  of  rural  areas  through  development  of  renewable  energy-based 
grid and off-grid connections.

considering shifting its traditional focus of assistance in the power sector from hydropower and 
thermal  power  generation  to  energy  conservation  and  renewable  energy,  particularly  in  the

(KfW),  has  provided  approximately  $400  million  in  mixed  credits,  mostly  for  power  plants  and 
turbine  modernization  projects.  KfW  also  supported  the  Government  in  energy  efficiency  and 
renewable energy development. Other bilateral sources providing export credits or mixed credits 
in the energy sector include Australia, Canada, Denmark, France, Italy, Spain, United Kingdom, 
and United States.

ADB  has  established  a  working  relationship  with  the  World  Bank  in  addressing  policy 
issues and coordinating lending and TA operations, and exchanges views with bilateral sources 
and the private sector. Both ADB and the World Bank emphasize the importance of improving 
the management of power utilities, tariff reform, energy efficiency improvement,  environmental 
protection,  and  a  greater  role  for  the  private  sector.  During  the  processing  of  the  Investment 
Program,  discussions  were  held  with  the  World  Bank,  JBIC,  and  KfW  to  ensure  that  their 
respective activities are complementary and to maintain consistency in policy advice.

6. 
ADB’s overall experience with energy and environment sector projects in the PRC has 
been  positive.  Projects  are  generally  well-designed  and  smoothly  implemented,  although  front 
end delays have occurred in some projects. Success is attributed to extensive preparation prior 
to ADB intervention, high sense of local ownership, effective leadership in project management 
offices, and timely policy and enterprise reforms. Delays have also occurred for some projects in 
loan  signing  and 
in  procurement,  construction,  and 
commissioning, but in most cases have not led to unsatisfactory performance. The Government 
has  implemented  reforms  on  investment  regulations,  which  simplify  approval  procedures  and 
delegate  some  approving  functions  to  authorities  at  the  local  governments.  ADB  has  been 
working  closely  with  the  Government  to  harmonize  the  two  approval  procedures  to  minimize 
project start-up and implementation delays.   
 
7. 
Power utilities, particularly small and medium ones, have been found to be weak in the 
area  of  commercial  and  financial  management.  Often,  there  is  a  need  for  institutional 
strengthening  in  the  areas  of  organizational  structure,  delegation  of  authority,  management, 
information  and  control  systems,  accounting  and  financial  management,  and  human  resource 
management.  Project  completion  and  project  performance  audit  reports  for  ADB-financed 
projects in  the  PRC  highlight  (i)  the  need  to improve  financial  reporting;  (ii)  the  need  for  more 
attention  to  environmental  matters;  (iii)  the  advisability  of  using  larger  boiler-turbine  units;  and 
(iv) the necessity for capacity building, not only for project preparation, but also for staff training  
in  operational  and  managerial  aspects  of  power  utility  operations.  Recently,  some  ongoing 
power  projects  in  the  PRC  experienced  implementation  delays  in  meeting  procurement  and 
construction  deadlines  mainly  because  of  the  ongoing  restructuring  of  the  power  sector  and

8. 
Ongoing reforms on power tariffs are encouraging increased use of renewable energies, 
including  wind,  solar,  small  and  medium  hydropower,  and  bioenergies.  The  retail  and  power 
plant output tariffs in the PRC are regulated. They are fixed by the price bureau of the National 
Development  and  Reform  Commission  (NDRC)  and,  in  the  case  of  power  plants,  are 
announced  at  the  beginning  of  the  year  for  units  commencing  their  commercial  operations 
during the year. In the ongoing sector reforms in the PRC, the retail tariffs are being unbundled 
into generation, and transmission and distribution tariffs. The fundamental principles of full cost 
recovery,  and  adequate  return  on  equity  and  interest  are  firmly  embedded  in  the  sector  tariff 
formulation for over a decade now and have been consistently applied. The project completion 
report on the two completed hydropower projects8 revealed that the tariff approved were lower 
than the appraisal estimate. However, the approved tariffs were still consistent with the average 
incremental  economic  cost  (AIEC)  of  hydropower  plants.  It  suggests  that  a  careful  approach 
based  on  more  rigorous  analysis  of  tariff-setting  guidelines  and  ongoing  reforms  should  be 
factored in the estimated tariffs, so that the project financial viability can be ascertained under 
the most likely scenario.  
 
9. 
Some hydropower projects (footnote 1) have also had substantial loan cancellations due 
to  cost  savings.  The  reason  was  that  cost  estimates  were  made  on  international  pricing 
standards  with  a  high  level  of  contingencies,  which  in  most  cases  were  not  utilized.  Some  
commitment  charges  were  avoidable.  There  should  be  a  more  careful  examination  of  all  cost 
components  and  a  review  of  historical  costs  for  similar  projects  in  the  PRC,  together  with  a 
proactive approach in identifying cost savings and prompt loan cancellations.  
 
10. 
These  lessons  were  taken  into  account  in  the  Investment  Program  design  and 
preparation.  During  the  preparation,  lessons  of  experience  were  addressed  by  (i)  thoroughly 
reviewing  project  readiness  on  key  factors  that  may  potentially  delay  the  start-up;  (ii) careful 
assessment  of  institutional  capacity  and  strengthening  measures  to  improve  the  level  of 
corporate  governance;  (iii)  conservative  estimates  of  the  expected  tariff  consistent  with  the 
existing policies and reform agenda; (iv) undertaking rigorous review and sensitivity analysis of 
cash  flows,  and  financial  and  economic  analyses;  and  (v)  setting  up  of  project  implementing 
units  with  autonomy  in  operations  and  for  procurement  decisions.  The  implementation  of  two 
ongoing hydropower projects9 in the PRC is rated as “highly satisfactory” suggesting that there
